title: Reed Hastings
content:
{{short description|American entrepreneur and education philanthropist (born 1960)}} {{Infobox person | name = Reed Hastings | image = Re publica 2015 - Tag 1 (17195424118).jpg | caption = Hastings in 2015 | birth_name = Wilmot Reed Hastings Jr. | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1960|10|8}} | birth_place = [[Boston]], [[Massachusetts]], U.S. | education = [[Bowdoin College]] (BA)
[[Stanford University]] (MS) | known_for = Co-founder and chairman, [[Netflix, Inc.|Netflix]] | spouse = {{marriage|Patricia Ann Quillin|1991}}{{Cite web |last=Scipioni |first=Jade |date=September 9, 2020 |title=The business lesson Reed Hastings learned from his marriage counselor that helped shape Netflix |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/09/business-lesson-netflixs-reed-hastings-got-from-marriage-counselor.html |publisher=CNBC}} | children = 2 }} '''Wilmot Reed Hastings Jr.''' (born October 8, 1960) is an American billionaire businessman. He is the co-[[Organizational founder|founder]] and executive chairman of [[Netflix, Inc.|Netflix]], and currently sits on a number of boards and [[non-profit organizations]]. A former member of the [[California State Board of Education]], he is also an advocate for [[education reform]] through [[charter schools]].{{cite web|url=http://news-service.stanford.edu/news/2000/april5/hastings-45.html|title=Charter schools advocate Reed Hastings to speak April 12: 4/00|website=news-service.stanford.edu}} ==Early life== Hastings was born in [[Boston, Massachusetts]]. His father Wilmot Reed Hastings Sr. was an attorney for the [[United States Department of Health, Education, and Welfare|Department of Health, Education and Welfare]] in the [[Nixon]] administration, and his mother Joan Amory Loomis was a [[debutante]] from a [[Boston Brahmin]] family who was repulsed by the world of [[high society (social class)|high society]] and taught her children to disdain it. {{cite web|url=https://humphrysfamilytree.com/Royal/Larson/a/Edw1-ReedHastings.pdf |title=Family Tree on Father's Side |publisher=humphrysfamilytree.com |date=July 4, 2017 |access-date=September 27, 2020}}{{cite web|url=http://humphrysfamilytree.com/Royal/Larson/Edw3-ReedHastings.pdf |title=Family Tree on Mother's Side |publisher=humphrysfamilytree.com |date=August 8, 2013 |access-date=February 5, 2020}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2006/12/17/jobs/17boss.html |title=Out of Africa, Onto the Web |date=December 17, 2006 |work=The New York Times |via=NYTimes.com}}{{cite news |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2020/09/04/style/reed-hastings-netflix-interview.html |title=Reed Hastings Had Us All Staying Home Before We Had To |date=September 4, 2020 |work=The New York Times |via=NYTimes.com}} His maternal great-grandfather was [[Alfred Lee Loomis]]. Hastings attended [[Buckingham Browne & Nichols School]] in [[Cambridge, Massachusetts]], and sold vacuum cleaners door-to-door in a [[gap year]] before entering college. In 1983, he graduated from [[Bowdoin College]] with a Bachelor of Arts degree in Mathematics, which he found "beautiful and engaging". He joined the [[United States Marine Corps|Marine Corps]] officer training through their Platoon Leader Class, and spent college summers in the Marines, including a stint at the Officer Candidate School boot camp at [[Marine Corps Base Quantico]], [[Virginia]] in the summer of 1981. He did not complete the training and never commissioned into the Marine Corps—choosing instead to pursue service in the [[Peace Corps]] “out of a combination of service and adventure”. He went to teach math at a high school of around 800 students in rural northwest [[Swaziland]] from 1983 to 1985 after college. He credits part of his entrepreneurial spirit to his time in the Peace Corps, remarking that, “Once you have hitchhiked across Africa with ten bucks in your pocket, starting a business doesn't seem too intimidating”.{{Cite web|url=https://www.inc.com/magazine/20051201/qa-hastings.html|title=How I Did It: Reed Hastings, Netflix, Internet Business Models Article|first=Reed|last=Hastings|date=December 1, 2005|website=Inc.com}}{{cite web|url=https://money.cnn.com/magazines/fortune/fortune_archive/2007/05/28/100034248/index.htm?section=money_latest |title=Questions for... Reed Hastings |date = May 28, 2007 |first = Matthew |last = Boyle |website=money.cnn.com}}{{Cite web|title=Netflix CEO Reed Hastings '83 Funds New Program for Student Success at Bowdoin {{!}} Bowdoin News Archive|url=http://community.bowdoin.edu/news/2017/09/netflix-ceo-reed-hastings-83-funds-new-program-for-student-success-at-bowdoin/|language=en-US|access-date=2020-05-15|archive-date=2017-09-25|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20170925170230/http://community.bowdoin.edu/news/2017/09/netflix-ceo-reed-hastings-83-funds-new-program-for-student-success-at-bowdoin/|url-status=dead}} After returning from the Peace Corps, Hastings went on to attend [[Stanford University]] after being rejected from his first choice [[MIT]], graduating in 1988 with a Master's Degree in [[Computer Science]].{{cite web|url=http://www.stanfordalumni.org/news/magazine/2006/janfeb/features/netflix.html|title=Stanford Magazine - Article|website=www.stanfordalumni.org}} == Career == === Founding of Pure Software === Hastings' first job was at Adaptive Technology, where he created a tool for debugging software.{{Cite book|last=Mookherji|first=Kalyani|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=wp_CDQAAQBAJ&q=reed+Hastings'+first+job+was+at+Adaptive+Technology,+where+he+invented+a+tool+for+debugging+software&pg=PT106|title=Digital Revolutionaries: Who Have Change the World|date=2017|publisher=Prabhat Prakashan|isbn=978-81-8430-523-4|language=en}} He met [[Audrey MacLean]] in 1990 when she was CEO at Adaptive Corp. In 2007, Hastings told CNN, "From her, I learned the value of focus. I learned it is better to do one product well than two products in a mediocre way." Hastings left Adaptive Technology in 1991 to lay the foundation to his first company, [[Pure Software]], which produced products to troubleshoot software. The company's growth proved challenging for Hastings, as he lacked managerial experience. He stated he had trouble managing with a rapid headcount growth. His engineering background didn't prepare him for the challenges of being a CEO, and he asked his board to replace him, stating he was losing confidence.{{cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/tech/products/services/2006-04-23-netflix-ceo_x.htm|title='Charismatic' founder keeps Netflix adapting - USATODAY.com|website=www.usatoday.com}} The board refused, and Hastings says he learned to be a businessman. Pure Software was taken public by [[Morgan Stanley]] in 1995. In 1996, Pure Software announced a merger with Atria Software. The merger integrated Pure Software's programs for detecting bugs in software with Atria's tools to manage development of complex software.{{Cite news|last=Journal|first=Don ClarkStaff Reporter of The Wall Street|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB834103937676602500|title=Software Firms Pure and Atria Agree to Merge in Stock Deal|date=1996-06-07|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2020-03-19|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}} The ''[[The Wall Street Journal|Wall Street Journal]]'' reported that there were problems integrating the sales forces of Pure Software and Atria after the head salesmen for both Pure and Atria left following the merger.{{Cite news|last=Journal|first=Don ClarkStaff Reporter of The Wall Street|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB86042439250896000|title=Investors Pan Rational's Plan To Buy Pure Atria for Stock|date=1997-04-08|work=Wall Street Journal|access-date=2020-03-19|language=en-US|issn=0099-9660}} In 1997, the combined company, [[Pure Atria]], was acquired by [[Rational Software]], which triggered a 42% drop in both companies' stocks after the deal was announced. Hastings was appointed Chief Technical Officer of the combined companies and left soon after the acquisition. After Pure Software, Hastings spent two years thinking about how to avoid similar problems at his next startup.{{cite news|url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2007-09-23/netflix-flex-to-the-max|title=Netflix: Flex To The Max|newspaper=Bloomberg |date=September 24, 2007|via=www.bloomberg.com}} === Founder of Netflix === {{Main|Netflix}} [[File:Netflix 2015 logo.svg|thumb|200 px|left|In 1997, Reed Hastings co-founded [[Netflix]], offering [[flat rate]] movie rental-by-mail to customers in the US]] In 1997, Hastings and former Pure Software employee [[Marc Randolph]] co-founded Netflix, offering [[flat rate]] movie rental-by-mail to customers in the US by combining two emerging technologies; DVDs, which were much easier to send as mail than VHS-cassettes, and a website from which to order them, instead of a paper catalogue.{{cite magazine|url=https://www.newyorker.com/magazine/2014/02/03/outside-the-box-2|title=The Red-Envelope Revolution|first=Ken|last=Auletta|magazine=The New Yorker|date=27 January 2014}} Headquartered in [[Los Gatos, California|Los Gatos]], California, Netflix has amassed a collection of 100,000 titles and more than 100 million subscribers.{{Cite web|url=https://venturebeat.com/2019/03/30/global-video-streaming-market-is-largely-controlled-by-the-usual-suspects/|title=Global video streaming market is largely controlled by the usual suspects|date=2019-03-31|website=VentureBeat|language=en-US|access-date=2020-03-19}} Hastings had the idea for Netflix after he left Pure Software. "I had a big late fee for ''[[Apollo 13 (film)|Apollo 13]]''. It was six weeks late and I owed the video store $40. I had misplaced the cassette. It was all my fault. I didn't want to tell my wife about it. And I said to myself, ‘I'm going to compromise the integrity of my marriage over a late fee?’ Later, on my way to the gym, I realized they had a much better business model. You could pay $30 or $40 a month and work out as little or as much as you wanted." Hastings said that when he founded Netflix, he had no idea whether customers would use the service. He is a proponent of [[Internet television]] and sees it as the future. He credits YouTube for his shift in strategy for developing a video streaming service.{{cite web |last=Stanford Graduate School of Business |date=October 15, 2014 |title=Reed Hastings, Netflix: Stanford GSB 2014 Entrepreneurial Company of the Year |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=zCO0lNfs4oM |url-status=live |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211221/zCO0lNfs4oM |archive-date=2021-12-21 |via=YouTube}}{{cbignore}} Netflix launched a service in 2007 to stream movies and television shows to computers. ==== Netflix culture ==== As [[Netflix]] grew, the company was noticed for its innovative management practices—the results of the culture Hastings was exploring—called “Freedom and Responsibility.” Netflix reportedly offers mediocre employees large severance packages to ensure that employees are consistently working to further the company's innovative environment. Netflix has eliminated sick and vacation time for employees, and instead allows them to manage their time off individually.{{Cite web|url=https://www.insider.com/people-with-unlimited-pto-policies-spend-every-vacation-working-2019-6|title=Is unlimited vacation a trap? It just might be.|last=Wang|first=Angela|website=Insider|access-date=2020-03-19}} Hastings created an internal culture guide for Netflix by meeting with employees to discuss the company's culture and employees' hypotheses about it. In August 2009, Hastings posted this internal culture guide publicly online, and it eventually became a pre-employment screening tool that dissuaded incompatible people from applying.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/emmazangs/2019/03/28/is-netflixs-2009-culture-deck-still-relevant-today-to-shape-company-culture/|title=Is Netflix's 2009 Culture Deck Still Relevant Today To Shape Company Culture?|last=Zangs|first=Emma|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=2020-03-19}} In September 2020, Hastings and [[Erin Meyer]] co-authored a book on Netflix's culture and management principles with interviews from current and former employees. ''No Rules Rules: Netflix and the Culture of Reinvention'' was a ''New York Times'' bestseller, featured on year-end lists for publications such as [[NPR]] and ''[[The Economist]]''. It was shortlisted for the [[Financial Times and McKinsey Business Book of the Year Award|''Financial Times'' and McKinsey Business Book of the Year Award]].{{Cite web |title=NPR's Book Concierge |url=https://apps.npr.org/best-books/#reset=true&view=covers&year=2020 |access-date=2021-01-07 |website=apps.npr.org}}{{Cite news |date=2020-12-03 |title=Our books of the year |url=https://www.economist.com/books-and-arts/2020/12/03/our-books-of-the-year |access-date=2021-01-07 |newspaper=The Economist}}{{Cite web |last=Hill |first=Andrew |date=2020-09-23 |title=FT/McKinsey business book of the year shortlist announced |url=https://www.ft.com/content/e33dfe64-5eed-4f1a-87d7-04008bbee809 |archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/archive/20221210/https://www.ft.com/content/e33dfe64-5eed-4f1a-87d7-04008bbee809 |archive-date=2022-12-10 |url-access=subscription |url-status=live |access-date=2021-01-07 |website=www.ft.com |language=en-GB}} === Other business ventures === Hastings was on the board of [[Microsoft]] from 2007 to 2012.{{cite press release |title=Microsoft Announces Reed Hastings Will Not Seek Re-Election |url=http://www.microsoft.com/en-us/news/Press/2012/Oct12/10-09ReedPR.aspx |publisher=Microsoft |access-date=December 28, 2012 |date=October 9, 2012}} He was also on the board of directors of [[Facebook, Inc.]] from June 2011{{cite press release|url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/facebook-names-reed-hastings-to-its-board-of-directors-124429638.html|title=Facebook Names Reed Hastings to Its Board of Directors|publisher=Facebook|via=PR Newswire}} to May 2019.{{cite web |last=Rodriguez |first=Salvador |date=April 12, 2019 |title=Netflix CEO Reed Hastings to depart Facebook board of directors |url=https://www.cnbc.com/2019/04/12/netflix-ceo-reed-hastings-to-depart-facebook-board-of-directors.html |website=CNBC}} As of September 2016, he was reported to own over US$10 million worth of Facebook shares.{{cite web|url=https://www.insidermole.com/insider/hastings-reed|title=REED HASTINGS Insider Trading Overview|website=www.insidermole.com|access-date=2016-09-27}} Hastings is the majority owner of [[Powder Mountain]] ski resort in Utah following his $100 million investment in 2023.{{Cite web |last=Raymond |first=Art |date=6 September 2023 |title=Netflix co-founder Reed Hastings is new majority owner of Powder Mountain following $100 million investment |url=https://www.deseret.com/2023/9/6/23861482/netflix-reed-hastings-new-owner-powder-mountain-resort-utah |website=Deseret News}}{{Cite news |last=Jag |first=Julia |date=6 September 2023 |title=Reed Hastings wants to turn around Powder Mountain, starting with a $100M investment |url=https://www.sltrib.com/sports/2023/09/06/powder-mountains-pivot-point-reed/ |work=The Salt Lake Tribune}} == Activism and philanthropy == === Education === ==== California State Board of Education ==== After selling Pure Software, Hastings found himself without a goal. He became interested in educational reform in California and enrolled in the [[Stanford Graduate School of Education]]. In 2000, Governor [[Gray Davis]] appointed Hastings to the [[California State Board of Education|State Board of Education]], and in 2001, Hastings became its president. He spent $1 million of his own money together with $6 million from Silicon Valley venture capitalist [[John Doerr]] to promote the passage of [[Proposition 39]] in November 2000,Wall Street Journal. "Silicon Valley Moguls Spend On Education Ballot Battles" by Ann Grimes. October 31, 2000. a measure that lowered the level of voter approval for local schools to pass construction bond issues from 66 to 55 percent.{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB120251714532955425|title=Movie Man|first=Jason|last=Riley|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|date=February 10, 2008|via=www.wsj.com}} In 2009, Hastings ran into trouble on the State Board of Education when Democratic legislators challenged his advocacy of more English instruction and language testing for non-English speaking students. The California Senate Rules Committee refused to confirm him as the board's president. The [[California State Legislature]] rejected him in January 2005.{{Cite web|url=http://www.cde.ca.gov/nr/ne/yr05/yr05rel8.asp|title=California Department of Education. "O'Connell on Reed Hastings - Year 2005." January 12, 2005.|access-date=January 15, 2006|archive-date=January 21, 2005|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050121225100/http://www.cde.ca.gov/nr/ne/yr05/yr05rel8.asp|url-status=dead}} Governor [[Arnold Schwarzenegger]], who had reappointed Hastings to the board after Hastings' first term, issued a statement saying he was “disappointed” in the committee's action. Hastings resigned.{{When|date=June 2020}} In April 2008, [[Steven Maviglio]] reported that Hastings had made a $100,000 contribution to California Governor Schwarzenegger's “Voters First” redistricting campaign.{{Cite web |url=http://www.camajorityreport.com/index.php?module=articles&func=display&aid=2968&ptid=9 |title=the California Majority Report. "Is Reed Hastings Six Figure Contribution to Schwarzenegger's Redistricting Effort Simple Revenge?" by Steven Maviglio. April 3, 2008. |access-date=April 7, 2008 |archive-date=September 12, 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20130912023409/http://www.camajorityreport.com/index.php?module=articles&func=display&ptid=9&aid=2968 |url-status=dead }} ==== Charter schools ==== Hastings is active in educational philanthropy and politics. One of the issues he most strongly advocates is [[charter schools]], publicly funded, privately-run elementary or secondary schools. In July 2006, the ''[[Santa Cruz Sentinel]]'' reported that Hastings had donated $1 million to Beacon Education Network to open up new charter schools in Santa Cruz County, where he lives.{{Cite web|url=http://www.santacruzsentinel.com/archive/2006/July/12/local/stories/03local.htm|title=Santa Cruz Sentinel. "Netflix CEO gives $1 million to open charter schools" by Matt King. July 11, 2006.|access-date=May 23, 2019|archive-date=August 6, 2020|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20200806151312/http://www.santacruzsentinel.com/archive/2006/July/12/local/stories/03local.htm|url-status=dead}} Hastings, as a [[Giving Pledge]] member since 2012, founded Hastings Fund and pledged $100 million to children's education.{{Cite web|url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/reed-hastings/|title=Reed Hastings|website=Forbes|language=en|access-date=2020-04-24}} In his post on Facebook, he said that the Hastings Fund "will donate these funds in the best way possible for kids' education."{{Cite web|url=http://philanthropynewsdigest.org/news/reed-hastings-creates-100-million-education-fund|title=Reed Hastings Creates $100 Million Education Fund|last=Candid|website=Philanthropy News Digest (PND)|language=en|access-date=2020-04-24}} Hastings Fund gave its first two gifts, totaling $1.5 million, to the [[United Negro College Fund]] and the Hispanic Foundation of Silicon Valley for college scholarships for black and Latino youth.{{Cite web|url=https://www.cnbc.com/2016/01/13/netflix-ceo-reed-hastings-starts-100m-fund-for-education.html|title=Netflix CEO Reed Hastings Starts $100M Fund for Education|last=Eng|first=James|date=2016-01-13|website=CNBC|language=en|access-date=2020-04-24}} In March 2014, he argued for the elimination of elected school boards.{{cite news|url=https://www.washingtonpost.com/news/answer-sheet/wp/2014/03/14/netflixs-reed-hastings-has-a-big-idea-kill-elected-school-boards/|title=Netflix's Reed Hastings has a big idea: Kill elected school boards (update)|first=Valerie|last=Strauss|newspaper=[[The Washington Post]] |date=March 14, 2014}} ==== Historically Black Colleges and Universities (HBCUs) ==== In June 2020, Hastings donated $120 million to be equally split among the [[United Negro College Fund]], [[Morehouse College]] and [[Spelman College]].{{Cite web |last=Togoh |first=Isabel |title=Netflix CEO Reed Hastings Donates $120 Million To HBCUs: 'We Hope This Will Help More Black Students Follow Their Dreams' |url=https://www.forbes.com/sites/isabeltogoh/2020/06/17/netflix-ceo-reed-hastings-donates-120-million-to-hbcus-we-hope-this-will-help-more-black-students-follow-their-dreams/ |access-date=2020-06-17 |website=Forbes |language=en}} It was the largest individual donation ever to support scholarships at HBCUs. === Donor-advised fund === Hastings opened a [[donor-advised fund]] at the [[Silicon Valley Community Foundation]] in 2016 with a $100{{nbsp}}million contribution.{{Cite news |last=Block |first=Fang |date=June 23, 2020 |title=Philanthropists Stepping up to Address Racial Equality |url=https://www.barrons.com/articles/philanthropists-stepping-up-to-address-racial-equality-01592943987 |work=Barron's}} In 2024, he gifted two million of his Netflix shares worth $1.1{{nbsp}}billion to the foundation.{{Cite news |last=Francis |first=Theo |date=January 29, 2024 |title=Netflix Co-Founder Gives $1.1 Billion in Shares to Silicon Valley Charity Favored by Billionaires |url=https://www.wsj.com/finance/investing/netflix-co-foundergives-1-1-billion-in-shares-to-silicon-valley-charity-favored-by-billionaires-aa8b4d47 |work=The Wall Street Journal}} === Technology === In April 2004, Hastings authored a ''Wall Street Journal'' op-ed advocating the [[Stock option expensing|expensing of stock options]].{{cite news|url=https://www.wsj.com/articles/SB108113352739374084|title=Expense It!|first=Reed|last=Hastings|newspaper=Wall Street Journal|date=April 5, 2004|via=www.wsj.com}} === Politics === In August 2007, the ''[[Los Angeles Times]]'' reported that Hastings had donated $1 million to a committee formed to support California State Superintendent of Schools [[Jack O'Connell (American politician)|Jack O'Connell]]'s candidacy for [[Governor of California]] in 2010.{{cite web|url=http://www.latimes.com/news/local/la-me-stategop1aug01,0,4553077.story?coll=la-home-center|title=State Republican Party floating in a tide of budgetary red ink|first=Evan|last=Halper|date=August 1, 2007|via=LA Times}} In April 2009, Hastings donated $251,491.03 to Budget Reform Now, a coalition supporting [[California Proposition 1A (2009)|California Propositions 1A]] to [[California Proposition 1F (2009)|1F]].{{cite web|url=http://cal-access.sos.ca.gov/Campaign/Committees/Detail.aspx?id=1315905&session=2009&view=late1 |title=California Secretary of State - CalAccess - Campaign Finance |publisher=Cal-access.sos.ca.gov |access-date=June 26, 2012}} Hastings supported [[Hillary Clinton]] in the [[2016 United States presidential election|2016 US presidential election]].{{cite news |date=July 23, 2016 |title=Hillary Clinton racks up business endorsements |url= https://www.politico.com/story/2016/06/business-leaders-endorse-hillary-clinton-224706 |newspaper=Politico }} In 2021, Hastings gave $3 million to defeat the [[2021 California gubernatorial recall election|campaign to recall Gavin Newsom]] as governor of California.{{Cite news|url=https://calmatters.org/politics/2021/05/gavin-newsom-recall-money/|title=Follow the money: Gavin Newsom recall edition|first=Jeremia|last=Kimelman|date=May 26, 2021|website=CalMatters}} == Personal life == Hastings lives in [[Santa Cruz, California]].{{cite web |title=Forbes profile: Reed Hastings |url=https://www.forbes.com/profile/reed-hastings-1/ |website=Forbes |access-date=25 July 2020}} He is married to Patricia Ann Quillin and has two children. He appeared in a front-page article in ''[[USA Today]]'' in 1995, posing on his [[Porsche]]. He considers that immature now and has said that if he ever appears on the front page of ''USA Today'' again it will "not [be] on the hood of a Porsche, but I would [pose] with a bunch of movies".Wall Street Journal. "Netflix's CEO Is Mobilizing For Battle With Amazon" by Carl Bialik. October 20, 2004.{{Relevance inline|date=June 2020}} Hastings sold his Porsche for a [[Toyota Avalon]], but now drives a [[Tesla, Inc.|Tesla]]. In 2018, Hastings appeared in a podcast series by [[LinkedIn|Linkedin]] co-founder [[Reid Hoffman]], ''[[Masters of Scale]]'', and discussed the strategy adopted by Netflix to scale.{{Cite web|url=https://mastersofscale.com/reed-hastings-culture-shock/|title=Reed Hastings on Masters of Scale}} In 2020, Hastings and his wife donated $30 million to [[GAVI]] to support [[COVAX]] [[COVID-19 vaccine]]s initiative.{{cite web |url=https://www.gavi.org/sites/default/files/covid/covax/COVAX-AMC-Donors-Table.pdf |title=Key Outcomes: COVAX AMC 2021 |publisher=Gavi}}{{Cite web|title=Reed Hastings and Patty Quillin support Gavi with US$ 30 million donation|url=https://www.gavi.org/news/media-room/reed-hastings-and-patty-quillin-support-gavi-us-30-million-donation|access-date=2021-08-26|website=www.gavi.org|date=7 November 2019 |language=en}} In [[2022 Russian invasion of Ukraine|March 2022]], Hastings donated $1 million to [[Razom]], a Ukrainian nonprofit organization that procures emergency supplies and medical equipment such as disposable resuscitators to treat the wounded.{{cite news |author=Andrew Jeong |language = en |url = https://www.washingtonpost.com/world/2022/03/03/donate-ukraine-money-crypto/ |title =What people are donating to Ukraine and its refugees: Crypto, ammo, pet food and cash |newspaper =The Washington Post |date = 2022-03-03 |accessdate = 2022-03-08}}{{cite web |language = en |url = https://www.businessinsider.in/tech/news/netflix-co-founder-reed-hastings-announces-1-million-donation-towards-ukraine-relief/amp_articleshow/89962953.cms |title =Netflix co-CEO announces $1 mn donation towards Ukraine relief |publisher = The Business Insider India |date = 2022-03-03 |accessdate = 2022-03-08}} In June 2022, Hastings delivered the [[Commencement speech|commencement address]] at Stanford University.{{Cite web |last=University |first=Stanford |date=2022-06-12 |title=Reed Hastings urges Class of 2022 to harness the power of inventions and stories |url=https://news.stanford.edu/2022/06/12/reed-hastings-urges-class-2022-harness-power-inventions-stories/ |access-date=2024-02-25 |website=Stanford News |language=en}} == References == {{reflist}} ==
